delete.description: Delete the given invocation. By default, an invocation is terminated by gracefully cancelling it. This ensures virtual object state consistency. Alternatively, an invocation can be killed which does not guarantee consistency for virtual object instance state, in-flight invocations to other services, etc. A stored completed invocation can also be purged

parameters.name: mode
parameters.description: If cancel, it will gracefully terminate the invocation. If kill, it will terminate the invocation with a hard stop. If purge, it will only cleanup the response for completed invocations, and leave unaffected an in-flight invocation.

parameters.name: sink
parameters.description: Filter by the exact specified sink.

parameters.name: source
parameters.description: Filter by the exact specified source.

get.description: Get the handler of a service

post.description: Create deployment. Restate will invoke the endpoint to gather additional information required for registration, such as the services exposed by the deployment. If the deployment is already registered, this method will fail unless `force` is set to `true`.

get.description: List all the handlers of the given service.

delete.description: Delete deployment. Currently it's supported to remove a deployment only using the force flag

parameters.name: force
parameters.description: If true, the deployment will be forcefully deleted. This might break in-flight invocations, use with caution.

501.description: Not implemented. Only using the force flag is supported at the moment.

get.summary: Get Virtual Object inbox inbox for a key
get.description: Get Virtual Object inbox inbox for a key

version.title: Version
version.description: If set, the latest version of the state is compared with this value and the operation will fail when the versions differ.

object_key.title: Service key
object_key.description: To what virtual object key to apply this change

new_state.title: New State
new_state.description: The new state to replace the previous state with

restate_code.title: Restate code
restate_code.description: Restate error code describing this error

name.title: Name
name.description: Fully qualified name of the service

deployment_id.title: Deployment Id
deployment_id.description: Deployment exposing the latest revision of the service.

public.title: Public
public.description: If true, the service can be invoked through the ingress. If false, the service can be invoked only from another Restate service.

idempotency_retention.title: Idempotency retention
idempotency_retention.description: The retention duration of idempotent requests for this service.

workflow_completion_retention.title: Workflow completion retention
workflow_completion_retention.description: The retention duration of workflows. Only available on workflow services.

inactivity_timeout.title: Inactivity timeout
inactivity_timeout.description:
This timer guards against stalled service/handler invocations. Once it expires, Restate triggers a graceful termination by asking the service invocation to suspend (which preserves intermediate progress).

The 'abort timeout' is used to abort the invocation, in case it doesn't react to the request to suspend.

Can be configured using the [`humantime`](https://docs.rs/humantime/latest/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html) format.

This overrides the default inactivity timeout set in invoker options.

abort_timeout.title: Abort timeout
abort_timeout.description:
This timer guards against stalled service/handler invocations that are supposed to terminate. The abort timeout is started after the 'inactivity timeout' has expired and the service/handler invocation has been asked to gracefully terminate. Once the timer expires, it will abort the service/handler invocation.

This timer potentially **interrupts** user code. If the user code needs longer to gracefully terminate, then this value needs to be set accordingly.

Can be configured using the [`humantime`](https://docs.rs/humantime/latest/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html) format.

This overrides the default abort timeout set in invoker options.

input_description.title: Human readable input description
input_description.description: If empty, no schema was provided by the user at discovery time.

output_description.title: Human readable output description
output_description.description: If empty, no schema was provided by the user at discovery time.

input_json_schema.title: Input JSON Schema
input_json_schema.description: JSON Schema of the handler input

output_json_schema.title: Output JSON Schema
output_json_schema.description: JSON Schema of the handler output

min_admin_api_version.title: Min admin API version
min_admin_api_version.description: Minimum supported admin API version by the admin server

max_admin_api_version.title: Max admin API version
max_admin_api_version.description: Maximum supported admin API version by the admin server

public.title: Public
public.description: If true, the service can be invoked through the ingress. If false, the service can be invoked only from another Restate service.

idempotency_retention.title: Idempotency retention
idempotency_retention.description:
Modify the retention of idempotent requests for this service.

Can be configured using the [`humantime`](https://docs.rs/humantime/latest/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html) format or the ISO8601.

workflow_completion_retention.title: Workflow completion retention
workflow_completion_retention.description:
Modify the retention of the workflow completion. This can be modified only for workflow services!

Can be configured using the [`humantime`](https://docs.rs/humantime/latest/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html) format or the ISO8601.

inactivity_timeout.title: Inactivity timeout
inactivity_timeout.description:
This timer guards against stalled service/handler invocations. Once it expires, Restate triggers a graceful termination by asking the service invocation to suspend (which preserves intermediate progress).

The 'abort timeout' is used to abort the invocation, in case it doesn't react to the request to suspend.

Can be configured using the [`humantime`](https://docs.rs/humantime/latest/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html) format or the ISO8601.

This overrides the default inactivity timeout set in invoker options.

abort_timeout.title: Abort timeout
abort_timeout.description:
This timer guards against stalled service/handler invocations that are supposed to terminate. The abort timeout is started after the 'inactivity timeout' has expired and the service/handler invocation has been asked to gracefully terminate. Once the timer expires, it will abort the service/handler invocation.

This timer potentially **interrupts** user code. If the user code needs longer to gracefully terminate, then this value needs to be set accordingly.

Can be configured using the [`humantime`](https://docs.rs/humantime/latest/humantime/fn.parse_duration.html) format or the ISO8601.

This overrides the default abort timeout set in invoker options.

services.title: Services
services.description: List of services exposed by this deployment.

services.title: Services
services.description: List of services exposed by this deployment.

options.title: Options
options.description: Additional options to apply to the subscription.

uri.title: Uri
uri.description: Uri to use to discover/invoke the http deployment.

additional_headers.title: Additional headers
additional_headers.description: Additional headers added to the discover/invoke requests to the deployment.

use_http_11.title: Use http1.1
use_http_11.description: If `true`, discovery will be attempted using a client that defaults to HTTP1.1 instead of a prior-knowledge HTTP2 client. HTTP2 may still be used for TLS servers that advertise HTTP2 support via ALPN. HTTP1.1 deployments will only work in request-response mode.

force.title: Force
force.description:
If `true`, it will override, if existing, any deployment using the same `uri`. Beware that this can lead in-flight invocations to an unrecoverable error state.

By default, this is `true` but it might change in future to `false`.

See the [versioning documentation](https://docs.restate.dev/operate/versioning) for more information.

dry_run.title: Dry-run mode
dry_run.description: If `true`, discovery will run but the deployment will not be registered. This is useful to see the impact of a new deployment before registering it.

arn.title: ARN
arn.description: ARN to use to discover/invoke the lambda deployment.

assume_role_arn.title: Assume role ARN
assume_role_arn.description: Optional ARN of a role to assume when invoking the addressed Lambda, to support role chaining

additional_headers.title: Additional headers
additional_headers.description: Additional headers added to the discover/invoke requests to the deployment.

force.title: Force
force.description:
If `true`, it will override, if existing, any deployment using the same `uri`. Beware that this can lead in-flight invocations to an unrecoverable error state.

By default, this is `true` but it might change in future to `false`.

See the [versioning documentation](https://docs.restate.dev/operate/versioning) for more information.

dry_run.title: Dry-run mode
dry_run.description: If `true`, discovery will run but the deployment will not be registered. This is useful to see the impact of a new deployment before registering it.
